cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the possible source - a minor slowly developing dimming at (S40E20) in AIA 193 around noon, corroborating the lat/lon derived by fitting with two coronagraphs perfectly. The CME is probably associated with an eruption of one of the narrow filaments stretching from SE to NW.

note: A faint narrow CME in SSE seen in early timestamps in both coronagraphs. No clear source have been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: There is no clear source in EUV imagery and the front of this CME can be fit with a very wide range of longitudes (from -30 to -70 deg), so only POS analysis is definitive.

note: Bright 3-part CME with an even wider shock front. The start of the CME might be a bit earlier but it is more likely that there is a preceding front of a narrower precursor CME that gets swept into the 2024-06-24T02:48Z CME. The clear source of this CME is an eruption starting around 2024-06-24T01Z off of or behind the SW limb and seen as an unusually long/persistant brightening off of the SW limb seen in AIA 131/335 between 2024-06-24T01Z and as opening  of field lines on/behind the SW limb in AIA 193/171 starting after 2024-06-24T01Z. The opening of field lines starts as relatively narrow but becomes wider after 2024-06-24T02Z and is followed by very high rising post-eruptive arcades seen  on/just behind the SW limb. It is likely that the eruption is from Active Region 3712 which was at ~S25W91 at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the assumption that the CME is associated with Active Region 3712 which was at S25W91 (behind the limb) at the time. The fit in two coronagraphs corroborates this.

note: A very faint CME with a fuzzy unclear front that is visible only in a few early timestamps in SOHO C2/C3 coronagraph and super faintly in STEREO A COR2. No source has been found.

cmeAnalyses.note: No clear source has been found. The fit with two coronagraphs can be obtained with longitudes from 60 to 90 degrees but the front is extremely faint in both coronagraphs. POS measurement is the only definitive measurement.

note: Narrow and faint CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Source is opening field lines seen starting around 2024-06-24T19:54Z in SDO AIA 171/193. Post-eruptive arcades become visible in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 starting around 2024-06-24T23:22Z. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to both faintness of the leading edge and a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-06-24T15:38Z to 2024-06-24T23:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using source location observed in UV imagery and best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to both faintness of the leading edge and a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-06-24T15:38Z to 2024-06-24T23:53Z.

note: Partial halo CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a large filament eruption. The filament extended from approximately N15W55 to S30W15 on the disk, with liftoff seen starting around 2024-06-24T21:40Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive loops are visible in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: A CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2, C3 and STEREO A COR2. The leading edge is unclear. Source is opening field lines seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193 and an M1.0 flare from Active Region 13723 peaking at 2024-06-25T12:45Z best seen in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of somewhat messy leading edge based on source location and best fit between coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME visible in the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SE in STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption centered around S10W05, between ARs 3719 and 3720. Liftoff and brightening starting around 2024-06-25T22:18Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME was difficult to measure due to it's faintness in available coronagraph imagery.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source may be beyond the west limb. Opening field lines are visible on/beyond the limb from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195 starting at approximately 2024-06-26T02:05Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, also taking in account source location beyond the west limb. Due to the uncertainty in source location, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible in the east of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Some candidate source eruptions in the east include a small eruption with brightening starting around 2024-06-26T05:40Z in SDO AIA 335 to the northeast of AR 3723 (approx. S15E50). Field line movement is also visible on the east limb in SDO AIA 171/193/335 as well, but there is no clear source eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 and candidate source location around longitude E50.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source can be seen near the limb in SDO AIA imagery, and it best seen as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at approximately 2024-06-26T09:30Z. The eruption is also visible in SDO AIA 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs, but only briefly in one frame of STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. The source is a long-duration eruption from AR 3728 alongside a long-duration C6.2 flare which peaked at 2024-06-26T15:30Z, best seen in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as some accompanying field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193 that gets deflected southward from this region, and some small brightening in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made mainly off of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery using the AR 3728 source longitude (with the observed southward deflection), with only one available STEREO COR2A frame making for an unideal triangulation.

note: CME seen to the SW in all coronagraphs. Source is likely an eruption near AR 3719, with a C2.0 class flare occurring just SW of the region, which peaked at 2024-06-27T17:12Z and best observed in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as field line motion and brightening of erupting material in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made via triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding some southward deflection from the source of AR 3719 (S17W42).

note: Thin CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is not certain, only potentially observed in SDO AIA 171 as moving field lines over the SE limb around 2024-06-28T20:55Z, indicating a source may exist on or near the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery given the uncertain source and poor STEREO COR2A running difference data quality as it is mid-campaign.

note: Faint partial halo seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and just to the SE in STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME is not entirely certain, but appears to originate from the cluster of ARs 3723, 3727, 3728, centered roughly around S20E25 (as such, this is used as the CME source coordinates). Some small C-class flaring is observed here as early as 2024-06-27T19:45Z, more noticeable closer to 2024-06-27T21:24Z possibly due to post-eruptive loops observed across SDO AIA 94/131/171/193. However, more confidence in this area is given via a good triangulation of the CME front between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A in swpc_cat when measuring.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made via triangulation of the front between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a fit roughly in the SE near the location of a cluster of ARs. The CME is notably faint and hard to follow in SOHO imagery due to the more direct angle, but STEREO imagery offers a better side-angle of the front that helps triangulate this as a front-sided longitude.

note: CME seen to the W in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain and unobserved in SDO AIA imagery, analyzed as a plane-of-sky for its speed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery given the uncertain source and poor STEREO COR2A running difference data quality as it is mid-campaign.

note: CME with a hazy leading edge seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption at S20W62, at AR 3719, starting at 2024-06-29T03:09Z as seen in SDO AIA 304. Ejecta can be seen throughout the eruption in SDO AIA 304 and 171. Opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193. Eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 193 and 304. The CME:2024-06-29T04:00Z overlaps with this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using source location seen in UV imagery and best fit between coronagraphs. STEREO-A was in a campaign which affected STEREO-A COR2 difference imagery for this CME.

note: Very faint loop CME seen to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a bit elusive, but may possibly be the liftoff of some filamentary material from one of the many filaments currently on the Earth-facing disk. Based on a stereoscopic measurement (with Lat:-17 and Lon:36), this may possibly be the liftoff of some material from a filament visible in SDO AIA 304 imagery which spanned from S40W10 to S25W60 at the start time of this CME. This CME overlaps with CME:2024-06-29T03:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using best fit between coronagraphs. STEREO-A was in a campaign which affected STEREO-A COR2 difference imagery for this CME.

note: Wide CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and S/SW in STEREO A COR2. The source is a large filament eruption spanning from S30E10 to S20W40. Liftoff seen starting at about 2024-06-29T15:09Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 193. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195/304 after a data gap from 2024-06-29T13:05Z to 2024-06-29T17:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SW in STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption centered around S55W30 in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-06-29T16:47Z. This partially overlaps with the filament eruption associated with CME: 2024-06-29T16:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption from AR 3719 (S15W65) with brightening and opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at 2024-06-29T21:08Z. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Very faint CME visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The start time is approximate due to the slow, faint nature of the CME in the field of view of SOHO LASCO C2, and the CME becomes more prominent in C2 around 2024-06-30T08:12Z. The source is unclear, but may be a slow eruption starting at 2024-06-30T00:07Z centered near the central meridian, around N20, best seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. Deflection in the field of view is possible, or a portion of the CME may not be measurable due to the CME's faintness.

note: Faint, narrow CME seen in the west of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME starts out slowly in SOHO LASCO C2. The source may be visible off the west limb as slow rising field lines in SDO AIA 171/193 around 2024-06-30T03:57Z. A faint dimming may also be seen on the disk, around N10W80, from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195, but this eruption is unclear.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO chosen due to limited usable STEREO A imagery, lack of clear measurable leading edge in coronagraph imagery, and the uncertainty in source location.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption best seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304 from AR 3719 in the southwest starting around 2024-06-30T13:37Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery usable for this measurement.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Only visible in early frames of STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-30T17:09Z to 2024-06-30T23:39Z. The source is an eruption from AR 3734 (approx. N10E65) which may have an associated C2.1 class flare peaking at 2024-06-30T15:49Z. Brightening is seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, based on source location.

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an M1.2 flare peaking at 2024-07-01T11:02Z from AR 3730 (approx. S19W37). The flare is best seen in SDO AIA 131, the ejection of material following the flare can be seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304, and opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171/193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location, with slight adjustment for best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. The CME may deflect in the field of view.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-07-01T13:09Z to 2024-07-02T03:09Z. The source is not clearly visible in available SDO or STEREO A EUV imagery, and may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of source location.

note: CME visible to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SE of STEREO A COR2. The source is likely a filament eruption centered around S35E10 with liftoff seen in SDO AIA 304 around 2024-07-02T02:27Z. Dimming in visible in SDO AIA 193, opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 171, and post-eruptive arcades are best seen in SDO AIA 193 and 335. The eruption is also visible in the SE from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. There may be a fainter front, possible a shock, ahead of this measurement, but it was deemed not measurable with available imagery. STEREO A imagery is limited to 2 frames due to ongoing campaign.

note: CME visible in the southwest of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not found in available EUV imagery, but faint field line movement may be seen beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-07-02T06:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The leading edge of this CME was not clearly measurable in STEREO A COR2. The plane-of-sky method was chosen due to lack of clear source location.

note: Faint CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Due to it's faintness, it is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption on or just beyond the east limb from the point of view of SDO EUV imagery. An eruption can be seen on the limb starting at 2024-07-02T05:20Z, around latitude S15, in SDO AIA 335. Opening field lines are also seen in SDO AIA 171/193, and post-eruptive loops are best seen in SDO AIA 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location on east limb using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only. The CME was not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery and was not utilized for this measurement. Due to the uncertainty in the source location on the limb, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source appears to be an eruption with moving/opening field lines from AR13730, possibly associated with a lower level C-class flare as seen in SDO/AIA 193 and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The leading edge becomes diffuse quickly and is difficult to track in later frames. This measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and after a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a C4.7 flare from AR3730 visible in SDO/AIA 131 with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of CME features using source location. STEREO A COR2 imagery was not usable in measurement due to ongoing campaign impacting difference imagery.

note: Faint narrow insignificant jet only seen in a couple of early timestamps of SOHO LASCO C3. No source found.
